conclusion: The graph shown represents the v-t (velocity-time) graph of a particle moving in a straight line, and the graph is symmetric about the dashed line in the figure.
The graph shows the velocity \\(v\\) as a function of time \\(t\\).
The graph is symmetric about the vertical dashed line, indicating that the particle's motion is symmetric around this point.
The graph starts at a positive velocity, decreases to zero, then increases back to a positive velocity.
At \\(t = 0\\), the particle has a positive velocity.
At some point between \\(0\\) and \\(t_1\\), the velocity reaches zero.
After reaching zero, the velocity becomes negative and then positive again.
Since the graph is symmetric about the dashed line, the motion from \\(0\\) to the point where the velocity is zero is mirrored from the point where the velocity is zero to \\(t_1\\).
The particle starts at a certain position with a positive velocity.
As it moves forward, it reaches a maximum distance from the starting point when the velocity is zero.
After this point, the particle reverses direction and moves back towards the starting point.
The particle continues to move forward until it reaches another point where the velocity is zero, which is symmetrically opposite to the first zero-velocity point.
Finally, the particle moves forward again until it reaches the same position it started from.
The particle must pass through the same position three times because of the symmetry of the graph.
The first time is at the start.
The second time is when the particle reaches the maximum distance from the starting point.
The third time is when the particle returns to the starting point after reversing direction.

The possible scenario for the motion of the particle is that it starts at a certain position, moves forward to a maximum distance, reverses direction, and returns to the starting position, passing through the same position three times.
The particle passes through the same position three times.
